title: Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: is an [mRNA](/wiki/MRNA_vaccine)-based [COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) developed by the German biotechnology company [BioNTech](/wiki/BioNTech). For its development, BioNTech collaborated with American company [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer) to carry out [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial), logistics, and manufacturing. [[40]](#cite_note-40) [[41]](#cite_note-nytimes-2020-11-09-41) It is authorized for use in people to provide protection against [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19), caused by infection with the [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2) [virus](/wiki/Virus). [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) [[26]](#cite_note-Pfizer-BioNTech_COVID-19_Vaccine_FDA_label-26) The vaccine is given It is composed of [nucleoside-modified mRNA](/wiki/Nucleoside-modified_messenger_RNA) mutated form of the [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2), which is encapsulated in [lipid nanoparticles](/wiki/Solid_lipid_nanoparticle). [[42]](#cite_note-pmid33053279-42) Initial advice indicated that vaccination required two doses given 21 days apart, [[30]](#cite_note-CDC_standing_order-30) [[43]](#cite_note-NCT04368728-43) [[44]](#cite_note-palca-44) [[45]](#cite_note-herper-45) but the interval was later extended to up to 42 days in the US, [[30]](#cite_note-CDC_standing_order-30) [[46]](#cite_note-46) and up to four months in Canada. [[47]](#cite_note-47) [[48]](#cite_note-48) Clinical trials began in April 2020; [[43]](#cite_note-NCT04368728-43) by November 2020, the vaccine entered [phase III clinical trials](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_III), with over 40,000 people participating. [[49]](#cite_note-BioNTechUpdate-49) An [interim analysis](/wiki/Interim_analysis) of study data showed a potential [efficacy](/wiki/Vaccine_efficacy) of 91.3% in preventing symptomatic infection within seven days of a second dose and no serious safety concerns. [[45]](#cite_note-herper-45) [[50]](#cite_note-:4-50) Most [side effects](/wiki/Side_effect) are mild to moderate in severity and are gone within a few days. [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) [[51]](#cite_note-:7-51) The most common include mild to moderate [pain](/wiki/Pain) at the injection site, [fatigue](/wiki/Fatigue), and [headaches](/wiki/Headache). [[52]](#cite_note-pmid33301246-52) [[53]](#cite_note-53) Reports of serious side effects, such as allergic reactions, are very rare [[a]](#cite_note-AEfrequency-55) and no long-term complications have been reported. [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) [[55]](#cite_note-nhs-cvac-56) The vaccine is the first COVID19 vaccine to be authorized by a [stringent regulatory authority](/wiki/Stringent_regulatory_authority) for emergency use [[56]](#cite_note-ukgov12-22-57) [[57]](#cite_note-boseley2-58) and the first cleared for regular use. [[37]](#cite_note-Swiss_authorization-37) In December 2020, the United Kingdom was the first country to authorize its use on an emergency basis. [[55]](#cite_note-nhs-cvac-56) It is authorized for use at some level in the majority of countries. [[58]](#cite_note-59) [[59]](#cite_note-60) [[60]](#cite_note-61) [[61]](#cite_note-62) On 23 August 2021, the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine became the first COVID-19 vaccine to be [approved](/wiki/Approved_drug) in the United States by the [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA). [[25]](#cite_note-FDA_Comirnaty-25) [[28]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20210823-28) [[62]](#cite_note-CNN_20210823-63) Distribution and storage is a logistical challenge because the vaccine needs to be stored at extremely low temperatures. [[63]](#cite_note-Rosales-2021-64) In August 2022, a bivalent version of the vaccine (Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine, Bivalent) was authorized for use as a [booster dose](/wiki/Booster_dose) in individuals twelve years of age and older in the United States. [[64]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20220831-65) [[65]](#cite_note-66) [[66]](#cite_note-67) [[67]](#cite_note-68) In September (Comirnaty Original/Omicron BA.1 or tozinameran/riltozinameran) [[68]](#cite_note-69) was authorized as a booster for use in the United Kingdom. [[69]](#cite_note-MHRA_PR_20220903-70) [[70]](#cite_note-71) [[71]](#cite_note-ema010922-72) In September 2022, the European Union authorized both the BA.1 and the BA.4/BA.5 (tozinameran/famtozinameran) booster versions of the bivalent vaccine. [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) [[3]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_Union_Register-3) [[36]](#cite_note-EMA_PR_20220916-36) Medical uses The Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine is used to provide protection against COVID-19, caused by infection with the [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2) virus, by eliciting an immune response to the S [antigen](/wiki/Antigen). [[1]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_SmPC-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) [[26]](#cite_note-Pfizer-BioNTech_COVID-19_Vaccine_FDA_label-26) [[35]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_FDA_label-35) The vaccine is used to reduce morbidity and mortality from COVID-19. [[30]](#cite_note-CDC_standing_order-30) The vaccine is supplied in a multidose vial as "a white to off-white, for [intramuscular injection](/wiki/Intramuscular_injection)". [[26]](#cite_note-Pfizer-BioNTech_COVID-19_Vaccine_FDA_label-26) [[35]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_FDA_label-35) [[72]](#cite_note-FDA_EUA_Report-73) It must be thawed to room temperature and diluted with [normal saline](/wiki/Normal_saline) before administration. [[35]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_FDA_label-35) [[72]](#cite_note-FDA_EUA_Report-73) The initial course consists of two doses. [[30]](#cite_note-CDC_standing_order-30) [[35]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_FDA_label-35) The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) recommends an interval of three to four weeks between doses. Delaying the second dose by up to twelve weeks increases [immunogenicity](/wiki/Immunogenicity), even in older adults, against all [variants of concern](/wiki/Variant_of_concern). [[73]](#cite_note-pitch-8weeks-74) Authors of the Pitch study think that the optimal interval against the [Delta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant) is around eight weeks, with longer intervals leaving receptors vulnerable between doses. [[73]](#cite_note-pitch-8weeks-74) A third, fourth, or fifth dose can be added in some countries. [[64]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20220831-65) [[74]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20210812-75) [[75]](#cite_note-CDC_immunocompromised-76) [[76]](#cite_note-EMA_extra_doses-77) [[77]](#cite_note-78) 1]](#cite_note-80) [case-control study](/wiki/Case-control_study) published in August 2021, found that two doses of the BNT162b2 (Pfizer) vaccine had 93.7% effectiveness against symptomatic disease caused by the alpha (B.1.1.7) variant and 88.0% effectiveness against symptomatic disease caused by the delta (B.1.617.2) variant. [[79]](#cite_note-LopezBernallAugust2021-81) Notably, effectiveness after one dose of the Pfizer vaccine was 48.7% against alpha and 30.7% against delta, similar to effectiveness provided by one dose of the [ChAdOx1](/wiki/ChAdOx1) nCoV-19 vaccine. [[80]](#cite_note-82) On 27 August, the U.S. [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) published a study reporting that the effectiveness against infection decreased from 91% (81-96%) to 66% (26-84%) when the [Delta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant) became predominant in the US, which may be due to unmeasured and residual [confounding](/wiki/Confounding) related to a decline in vaccine effectiveness over time. [[81]](#cite_note-83) Unless indicated otherwise, the following effectiveness ratings are indicative of clinical effectiveness two weeks after the second dose. A vaccine is generally considered effective if the estimate is 50% with a >30% lower limit of the 95% [confidence interval](/wiki/Confidence_interval). [[82]](#cite_note-84) Effectiveness is generally expected 2020 to 1 February 2021 in Israel. [[84]](#cite_note-86)During this period, according to [Nextstrain](/wiki/Nextstrain), the dominant variant in Israel was lineage B.1.1.50 and the Alpha variant was becoming dominant. - ^ [a](#cite_ref-effectiveness-hospitalization_93-0) [b](#cite_ref-effectiveness-hospitalization_93-1) [c](#cite_ref-effectiveness-hospitalization_93-2) [d](#cite_ref-effectiveness-hospitalization_93-3)Preliminary data of effectiveness against hospitalization referenced Health England. [[88]](#cite_note-91) [[89]](#cite_note-briefing17-92) [^](#cite_ref-95)Effectiveness drops to 49% (24-65%) in weeks 10-14 after the second dose and then stabilizes at 34%-37% thereafter. [[90]](#cite_note-who-update-14december-94) [^](#cite_ref-effectiveness-no-ci_96-0)A [confidence interval](/wiki/Confidence_interval)was not provided, so it is not possible to know the accuracy of this measurement. [^](#cite_ref-98)Booster dose. [^](#cite_ref-100)Efficacy data from a study with more than 10,000 participants. [[92]](#cite_note-pfizer-pr-delta-booster-efficacy-99) [^](#cite_ref-102)Effectiveness drops to about 45% 10 weeks after the booster dose. [[93]](#cite_note-uk-vaccine-surveillance-23december-101) [[90]](#cite_note-who-update-14december-94) On 12 November, Public Health England reported a possible but extremely small reduction in effectiveness against symptomatic disease from the Delta sublineage AY.4.2 at longer intervals after the second dose. [[94]](#cite_note-briefing28-103) Preliminary data suggest that the effectiveness against the Omicron variant starts to decline in about 10 weeks, either after the initial two-dose regimen or after the booster dose. [[90]](#cite_note-who-update-14december-94) [[93]](#cite_note-uk-vaccine-surveillance-23december-101) For other variants, the effectiveness of the initial doses starts to decline in about six months. [[95]](#cite_note-104) A case-control study in Qatar from 1 January to 5 September 2021 found that effectiveness against infection peaked at 78% (95% CI, 76-79%) in the first month after the second dose, followed by a slow decline that accelerated after the fourth month, reaching 20% at months 5 to 7. A similar trajectory was observed against symptomatic disease and against specific variants. Effectiveness against severe disease, hospitalization and death was more robust, peaking at 96% (93-98%) in the second month and remaining almost stable through the sixth month, declining thereafter. [[96]](#cite_note-105) On 21 October, a phase 3 trial showed that a booster dose given approximately 11 months after the second dose restored the protective effect to the 96% (95% CI, 89-99%) efficacy level against symptomatic disease from the Delta variant. [[97]](#cite_note-106) [[92]](#cite_note-pfizer-pr-delta-booster-efficacy-99) On 8 December, Pfizer and BioNTech reported that preliminary data indicated that a third dose of the vaccine would provide a similar level of neutralizing antibodies against the [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant) as seen after two doses against other variants. [[98]](#cite_note-107) On 14 December, private health insurer [Discovery Health](/wiki/Discovery_Limited), in collaboration with the [South African Medical Research Council](/wiki/South_African_Medical_Research_Council), reported that real-world data from more than 211,000 cases of COVID-19 in South Africa, of which 78,000 were of the [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant), indicate that effectiveness against the variant after two doses is about 70% against hospital admission and 33% against symptomatic disease. Protection against hospital admission is maintained for all ages and groups with comorbidities. [[99]](#cite_note-108) A study of the bivalent booster effectiveness against severe COVID-19 outcomes in Finland, September 2022-January 2023, has shown that it reduced the risk of severe COVID-19 outcomes among the elderly. By contrast, among the chronically-ill 18-64-year-olds the risk was similar among those who received bivalent vaccine and those who did not. Among the elderly a bivalent booster provided highest protection during the first two months after vaccination, but thereafter signs of waning were observed. The effectiveness among individuals aged 65-79 years and those aged 80 years or more was similar. [[100]](#cite_note-109) Specific populations Based on the results of a preliminary study, the U.S. [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) recommends that pregnant women get vaccinated with the COVID19 vaccine. [[101]](#cite_note-110) [[102]](#cite_note-111) A statement by the British [Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency](/wiki/Medicines_and_Healthcare_products_Regulatory_Agency) (MHRA) and the [Commission on Human Medicines](/wiki/Commission_on_Human_Medicines) (CHM) reported that the two agencies had reached a conclusion that the vaccine is safe and effective in children aged between 12 and 15 years. [[103]](#cite_note-:5-112) [[104]](#cite_note-:6-113) On 19 May 2021, experts commissioned by the [Norwegian Medicines Agency](/wiki/Norwegian_Medicines_Agency) concluded that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is the likely cause of ten deaths of frail elderly patients in Norwegian nursing homes. They said that people with very short life expectancies have little to gain from vaccination, having a real risk of adverse reactions in the last days of life and of dying earlier. [[105]](#cite_note-114) A 2021 report by the [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales) Government ( [NSW Health](/wiki/NSW_Health)) in Australia found that the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is safe for those with various forms of [immunodeficiency](/wiki/Immunodeficiency) or [immunosuppression](/wiki/Immunosuppression), though it does note that the data on said groups is limited, due to their exclusion from many of the vaccine earlier trials held in 2020. It notes that the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) advises that the vaccine is among the three COVID-19 vaccines (alongside that of Moderna and [AstraZeneca](/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine)) it deems safe to give to immunocompromised individuals, and that expert consensus generally recommends their vaccination. The report states that the vaccines were able to generate an immune response in those individuals, though it does also note that this response is weaker than in those that are not immunocompromised. It recommends that specific patient groups, such as those with [cancer](/wiki/Cancer), [inflammatory bowel disease](/wiki/Inflammatory_bowel_disease) and various [liver diseases](/wiki/Liver_disease) be prioritised in the vaccination schedules over other patients that do not have said conditions. [[106]](#cite_note-115) On 20 September 2021, Pfizer announced that a clinical trial conducted in more than 2,200 children aged 5-11 has generated a "robust" response and is safe. [[107]](#cite_note-116) [[108]](#cite_note-117) Adverse effects In large phase 3 trials for the vaccine there were no reported serious safety findings, and it observed low incidence of serious adverse events. [[45]](#cite_note-herper-45) [[50]](#cite_note-:4-50) Most [side effects](/wiki/Side_effect) of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID19 vaccine are mild to moderate in severity and are gone within a few days. [[51]](#cite_note-:7-51) [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) They are similar to other adult vaccines and are normal signs that the body is building protection to the virus. [[51]](#cite_note-:7-51) During clinical trials, the common side effects affecting more than 1 in 10 people are (in order of frequency): pain and swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle aches, chills, joint pain, and fever. [[109]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_product_information-118) Fever is more common after the second dose. [[109]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_product_information-118) The [European Medicines Agency](/wiki/European_Medicines_Agency) (EMA) regularly reviews the data on the vaccine's safety. The safety report published on 8 September 2021, by the EMA was based on over 392 million doses administered in the European Union. [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) According to the EMA "the benefits of Comirnaty in preventing COVID19 continue to outweigh any risks, and there are no recommended changes regarding the use of this vaccine." [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) Rare side effects (that may affect up to 1 in 1,000 people) include temporary one sided facial drooping and allergic reactions such as hives or swelling of the face. [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) Allergy Documented hypersensitivity to polyethylene glycol (PEG) (a very rare allergy) is listed as a contraindication to the COVID-19 Pfizer vaccine. [[110]](#cite_note-119) [Severe allergic reaction](/wiki/Anaphylaxis) has been observed in approximately eleven cases per million doses of vaccine administered. [[111]](#cite_note-:1-120) [[112]](#cite_note-EU_safety_update-121) According to a report by the US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention), 71% of those allergic reactions happened within 15 minutes of vaccination and mostly (81%) among people with a documented history of allergies or allergic reactions. [[111]](#cite_note-:1-120) The UK's [Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency](/wiki/Medicines_and_Healthcare_products_Regulatory_Agency) (MHRA) advised on 9 December 2020 that people who have a history of "significant" allergic reaction should not receive the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID19 vaccine. [[113]](#cite_note-mhra-allergy-122) [[114]](#cite_note-WP-20201209-123) [[115]](#cite_note-cekdis20-124) On 12 December, the Canadian regulator followed suit, noting that: "Both individuals in the U.K. had a history of severe allergic reactions and carried adrenaline auto injectors. They both were treated and have recovered." [[116]](#cite_note-hc12dec-125) Myocarditis In June 2021, the [Israel's Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Israel)) announced a probable relationship between the second dose and [myocarditis](/wiki/Myocarditis) in a small group of 16-30-year-old men. [[117]](#cite_note-:8-126) Between December 2020 and May 2021, there were 55 cases of myocarditis per 1 million people vaccinated, 95% of which were classified as mild and most spent no more than four days in the hospital. [[117]](#cite_note-:8-126) Since April 2021, increasing number of cases of myocarditis and pericarditis have been reported in the United States in about 13 per 1 million young people, mostly male and over the age of 16, after vaccination with the Pfizer-BioNTech or the [Moderna vaccine](/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine). [[118]](#cite_note-127) [[119]](#cite_note-biontech-128) Most affected individuals recover quickly with adequate treatment and rest. [[120]](#cite_note-129) Since February 2022, the German [Standing Committee on Vaccination](/wiki/Standing_Committee_on_Vaccination) recommends [aspiration](/wiki/Injection_(medicine)#Aspiration) for COVID-19 vaccination as precautionary measure. [[121]](#cite_note-130) Pharmacology The BioNTech technology for the BNT162b2 vaccine is based on use of [nucleoside-modified mRNA](/wiki/Nucleoside-modified_messenger_RNA) (modRNA) which encodes a mutated form of the full-length [spike protein](/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein) found on the surface of the [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2) virus, [[122]](#cite_note-131) triggering an [immune response](/wiki/Immune_response) against infection by the virus protein. [[123]](#cite_note-gaebler-132) Sequence The modRNA sequence of the vaccine is 4,284 nucleotides long. [[124]](#cite_note-MedNet-133) It consists of a [five-prime cap](/wiki/Five-prime_cap); a [five prime untranslated region](/wiki/Five_prime_untranslated_region) derived [human cause the spike to adopt a prefusion-stabilized conformation reducing the membrane fusion ability, increasing expression and stimulating neutralizing antibodies; [[42]](#cite_note-pmid33053279-42) [[125]](#cite_note-pmid_=_28807998-134) a codon-optimized (bases followed by a [three prime untranslated region](/wiki/Three_prime_untranslated_region) (bases 3880-4174) combined from AES and [mtRNR1](/wiki/MT-RNR1) selected for increased protein expression and mRNA stability [[126]](#cite_note-135) and a [poly(A) tail](/wiki/Polyadenylation) comprising 30 adenosine residues, a 10-nucleotide linker sequence, and 70 other adenosine residues (bases 4175-4284). [[124]](#cite_note-MedNet-133) The sequence contains no [uridine](/wiki/Uridine) [1-methyl-3'-pseudouridylyl](/wiki/1-methyl-3%27-pseudouridylyl). [[124]](#cite_note-MedNet-133) The 2P proline substitutions in the spike proteins were originally developed for a [Middle East respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome) (MERS) vaccine by researchers at the [National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases](/wiki/National_Institute_of_Allergy_and_Infectious_Diseases)' [Vaccine Research Research](/wiki/Scripps_Research), and at Austin](/wiki/University_of_Texas_at_Austin), previously at [Dartmouth College](/wiki/Dartmouth_College)). [[125]](#cite_note-pmid_=_28807998-134) Chemistry In addition to the mRNA molecule, the vaccine contains the are [lipids](/wiki/Lipid). The lipids and modRNA together form [nanoparticles](/wiki/Nanoparticles) that act not only as carriers to get the modRNA into the human cells, but also as [adjuvants](/wiki/Immunologic_adjuvant). [[127]](#cite_note-136) ALC-0159 is a [polyethylene glycol](/wiki/Polyethylene_glycol) lipid. [[128]](#cite_note-parauk-137) Manufacturing Pfizer and BioNTech are manufacturing the vaccine in their own facilities in the United States and in Europe. The license to distribute and manufacture the vaccine in China was purchased by Fosun, alongside its investment in BioNTech. [[41]](#cite_note-nytimes-2020-11-09-41) [[129]](#cite_note-fosun-138) Manufacturing the vaccine requires a three-stage process. The first stage involves the [molecular cloning](/wiki/Molecular_cloning) of DNA [plasmids](/wiki/Plasmid) that code for the spike protein by infusing them into [Escherichia coli](/wiki/Escherichia_coli) bacteria. For all markets, this stage is conducted in the United States, [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) at a small Pfizer [[132]](#cite_note-Gosk-141) (near [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis)). After four days of growth, the bacteria are killed and [broken open](/wiki/Lysis), and the contents of their cells are purified over a week and a half to recover the desired DNA product. The DNA is bottled and frozen for shipment. Safely and quickly transporting the DNA at this stage is so important that Pfizer has used its company jet and helicopter to assist. [[133]](#cite_note-Johnson-142) The second stage is being conducted at a Pfizer plant in [Andover, Massachusetts](/wiki/Andover,_Massachusetts), [[134]](#cite_note-Hughes-143) in the United States, and at BioNTech's plants in Germany. [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) The DNA [is used as a template to build](/wiki/Transcription_(biology)) the desired mRNA strands, [[133]](#cite_note-Johnson-142) which takes about four days. [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) Once the mRNA has been created and purified, it is frozen in plastic bags about the size of a large shopping bag, of which each can hold up to 10 million doses. The bags are placed on trucks which take them to the next plant. [[133]](#cite_note-Johnson-142) The third stage is being conducted at Pfizer plants in [Portage, Michigan](/wiki/Portage,_Michigan) [[135]](#cite_note-Shamus-144) (near [Kalamazoo](/wiki/Kalamazoo,_Michigan)) in the United States, and [Puurs](/wiki/Puurs) in Belgium. This stage involves combining the mRNA with lipid nanoparticles, then filling vials, boxing vials, them. [[133]](#cite_note-Johnson-142) [Croda International](/wiki/Croda_International) Polar Lipids is providing the requisite lipids. [[136]](#cite_note-Mullin-145) As of November 2020, the major bottleneck in the manufacturing process is combining mRNA with lipid nanoparticles. [[133]](#cite_note-Johnson-142) At this stage, it takes only four days to go from mRNA and lipids to finished vials, but each lot must then spend several weeks in deep-freeze storage while undergoing verification against 40 quality-control measures. [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) Before May 2021, [[137]](#cite_note-Panetta-146) the Pfizer plant in Puurs was responsible for all vials for destinations outside the United States. [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) Therefore, all doses administered in the Americas outside of the United States before that point in time required at least two [transatlantic flights](/wiki/Transatlantic_flight) (one to take DNA to Europe and one to bring back finished vaccine vials). [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) In February 2021, BioNTech announced it would increase production by more than 50% to manufacture 2 billion doses in 2021, [[138]](#cite_note-147) raised again at the end of March to 2.5 billion doses in 2021. [[139]](#cite_note-Bloom2p5b-148) In February 2021, Pfizer revealed that the entire sequence initially took about 110 days on average from start to finish, and that the company is making progress on reducing the time to 60 days. [[140]](#cite_note-Weise-149) More than half the days in the production process are dedicated to rigorous testing and quality assurance at each of the three stages. [[140]](#cite_note-Weise-149) Pfizer also revealed that the process requires 280 components and relies upon 25 suppliers located in 19 countries. [[130]](#cite_note-Rabson-139) Vaccine manufacturers normally take several years to optimize the process of making a particular vaccine for speed and cost-effectiveness before attempting large-scale production. [[140]](#cite_note-Weise-149) Due to the urgency presented by the COVID19 pandemic, Pfizer and BioNTech began production immediately with the process by which the vaccine had been originally formulated in the laboratory, then started to identify ways to safely speed up and scale up that process. [[140]](#cite_note-Weise-149) BioNTech announced in September 2020, that it had signed an agreement to acquire a manufacturing facility in [Marburg](/wiki/Marburg), Germany, from [Novartis](/wiki/Novartis) to expand their vaccine production capacity. [[141]](#cite_note-:3-150) Once fully operational, the facility would produce up to 750 million doses per year, or more than 60 million doses per month. The site will be the third BioNTech facility in Europe that produces the vaccine, while Pfizer operates at least four production sites in the United States and Europe. [[141]](#cite_note-:3-150) The Marburg facility had previously specialized in [cancer immunotherapy](/wiki/Cancer_immunotherapy) for Novartis. [[142]](#cite_note-Solomon-151) By the end of March 2021, BioNTech had finished retrofitting the facility for mRNA vaccine production and retraining its 300 staff, and obtained approval to begin manufacturing. [[142]](#cite_note-Solomon-151) Besides making mRNA, the Marburg facility also performs the step of combining mRNA with lipids to form lipid nanoparticles, then ships the vaccine in bulk to other facilities for [fill and finish](/wiki/Fill_and_finish) (i.e., filling and boxing vials). [[142]](#cite_note-Solomon-151) On 23 April 2021, the EMA authorized an increase in batch size and associated process scale up at Pfizer's plant in Puurs. This increase is expected to have a significant impact on the supply of the vaccine in the European Union. [[143]](#cite_note-152) [[144]](#cite_note-153) At the end of April 2021, it was reported that Pfizer had started to export vaccine doses to Mexico and Canada from the Kalamazoo plant, which is much closer geographically to both countries than the Puurs plant. [[137]](#cite_note-Panetta-146) Logistics The vaccine is delivered in vials that, once diluted, contain 2.25 mL of vaccine, comprising 0.45 mL frozen and 1.8 mL diluent. [[145]](#cite_note-EUA_fact_sheet-154) According to the vial labels, each vial contains five 0.3 mL doses, however excess vaccine may be used for one, or possibly two, additional doses. [[145]](#cite_note-EUA_fact_sheet-154) [[146]](#cite_note-Pfizer-BioNTech_COVID-19_Vaccine_FAQ-155) The use of [low dead space syringes](/wiki/Low_dead_space_syringe) to obtain the additional doses is preferable, and partial doses within a vial should be discarded. [[145]](#cite_note-EUA_fact_sheet-154) [[147]](#cite_note-EU_dose-156) The [Italian Medicines Agency](/wiki/Italian_Medicines_Agency) officially authorized the use of excess doses remaining within single vials. [[148]](#cite_note-157) The [Danish Health Authority](/wiki/Danish_Health_Authority) allows mixing partial doses from two vials. [[149]](#cite_note-158) As of 8 January 2021, each vial contains six doses. [[109]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_product_information-118) [[150]](#cite_note-159) [[151]](#cite_note-160) [[147]](#cite_note-EU_dose-156) In the United States, vials will be counted as five doses when accompanied by regular syringes and as six doses when accompanied by low dead space syringes. [[152]](#cite_note-161) The vaccine can be stored at 2 to 8 °C (36 to 46 °F) for thirty days before use [[153]](#cite_note-162) [[154]](#cite_note-163) and at 25 °C °C (86 °F) [[155]](#cite_note-164) [[7]](#cite_note-AusPAR:_Tozinameran-7) for up to two hours before use. During distribution the vaccine is stored in special containers that maintain temperatures between 80 and 60 °C (112 and 76 °F). [[156]](#cite_note-Vaccination_Storage-165) Low-income countries have limited [cold chain](/wiki/Cold_chain) capacity for ultracold transport and storage of a vaccine. [[157]](#cite_note-bloom11-10-166) The necessary storage temperatures for the vaccine [[156]](#cite_note-Vaccination_Storage-165) [[158]](#cite_note-bbc-167) [[157]](#cite_note-bloom11-10-166) [[159]](#cite_note-168) [[160]](#cite_note-169) are much lower than The head of [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia)'s [Bio Farma](/wiki/Bio_Farma) Honesti Basyir said purchasing the vaccine is out of the question for the world's fourth-most populous country, given that it did not have the necessary cold chain capability. Similarly, India's existing cold chain network can handle only temperatures between 2 and 8 °C (36 and 46 °F), far above the requirements of the vaccine. [[161]](#cite_note-170) [[162]](#cite_note-171) History Before COVID19 vaccines, a vaccine for an infectious disease had never before been produced in less than several years, and no vaccine existed for preventing a [coronavirus](/wiki/Coronavirus) infection in humans. [[163]](#cite_note-gates2-172) The [SARS-CoV-2 virus](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2), which causes COVID19, was detected in December 2019, [[164]](#cite_note-who-time-173) and BioNTech began development of a COVID19 vaccine on 10 January 2020, when the SARS-CoV-2 [genetic sequences](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_sequence) were released by the [Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Chinese_Center_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) triggering an urgent international response to prepare for an outbreak and hasten development of preventive vaccines. [[165]](#cite_note-thanh-174) [[166]](#cite_note-Fauci-175) The vaccine's development began when BioNTech founder [Uur ahin](/wiki/U%C4%9Fur_%C5%9Eahin) read an article in the medical journal [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet) that convinced him the COVID19 coronavirus in China would soon become a global pandemic, so he called for scientists at the company to cancel their vacations and start development of a COVID19 vaccine in January 2020. [[167]](#cite_note-NYT_20201110-176) BioNTech started its program 'Project Lightspeed' to develop a vaccine against the new COVID19 virus based on its already established mRNA-technology, [[49]](#cite_note-BioNTechUpdate-49) which they had been developing since leading mRNA researcher [Katalin Karikó](/wiki/Katalin_Karik%C3%B3) joined the company in 2013. [[168]](#cite_note-177) Several variants of the vaccine were created in their laboratories in [Mainz](/wiki/Mainz), and 20 of those were presented to experts of the [Paul Ehrlich Institute](/wiki/Paul_Ehrlich_Institute) in [Langen](/wiki/Langen,_Hesse). [[169]](#cite_note-Chronology-178) Meanwhile, since 2018, Pfizer had been working with BioNTech on developing a mRNA vaccine for [influenza](/wiki/Influenza), but the chief executive officers of the two companies did not become personally acquainted until COVID-19 came along. [[170]](#cite_note-RaviVibha-179) After a few phone calls, Pfizer CEO [Albert Bourla](/wiki/Albert_Bourla) and ahin agreed that their companies would work together on the development of BioNTech's COVID-19 vaccine. [[170]](#cite_note-RaviVibha-179) To the horror of Pfizer's lawyers, the two agreed to begin work immediately, because [time was of the essence](/wiki/Time_is_of_the_essence), with no formal written legal agreement in place to govern the new collaboration. [[170]](#cite_note-RaviVibha-179) BioNTech transferred its [know-how](/wiki/Know-how) to Pfizer the next day. [[170]](#cite_note-RaviVibha-179) A [letter of intent](/wiki/Letter_of_intent) was signed three weeks later, and the formal commercial agreement between Pfizer and BioNTech for the COVID-19 vaccine was signed in January 2021. [[170]](#cite_note-RaviVibha-179) Funding According to Pfizer, research and development for the vaccine cost close to US$1 billion. [[171]](#cite_note-180) BioNTech received a US$135 million investment from Fosun in March 2020, in exchange for 1.58 million shares in BioNTech and the future development and marketing rights of BNT162b2 in China. [[172]](#cite_note-Fosun_PR_20200315-181) [[129]](#cite_note-fosun-138) In April 2020, BioNTech signed a partnership with Pfizer and received $185 million, including an equity investment of approximately $113 million. [[173]](#cite_note-182) [[174]](#cite_note-PR_20200409-183) [[175]](#cite_note-Pfizer_Annual_Report_2020-184) In June 2020, BioNTech received million million) in financing from Commission](/wiki/European_Commission) [European Investment Bank](/wiki/European_Investment_Bank). [[176]](#cite_note-eib-185) The Bank's deal with BioNTech started early in the pandemic, when the Bank's staff reviewed its portfolio and came up with BioNTech as one of the companies capable of developing a COVID19 vaccine. The European Investment Bank had already signed a first transaction with BioNTech in 2019. [[177]](#cite_note-186) In September 2020, the German government granted BioNTech €375 million (US$445 million) for its COVID19 vaccine development program. [[178]](#cite_note-187) Pfizer CEO [Albert Bourla](/wiki/Albert_Bourla) said he decided against taking funding from the US government's [Operation Warp Speed](/wiki/Operation_Warp_Speed) for the development of the vaccine "because I wanted to liberate our scientists [from] any bureaucracy that comes with having to give reports and agree how we are going to spend the money in parallel or together, etc." Pfizer did enter into an agreement with the US for the eventual distribution of the vaccine, as with other countries. [[179]](#cite_note-188) Clinical trials Phase I-II Trials were started in Germany on 23 April 2020, and in the U.S. on 4 May 2020, with four vaccine candidates entering clinical testing. [[43]](#cite_note-NCT04368728-43) [[49]](#cite_note-BioNTechUpdate-49) The vaccine candidate BNT162b2 was chosen as the most promising among three others with similar technology developed by BioNTech. [[123]](#cite_note-gaebler-132) Before choosing BNT162b2, [BioNTech](/wiki/BioNTech) and [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer) had conducted [phase I trials](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_I) on BNT162b1 in Germany and the United States, while Fosun performed a Phase I trial in China. In these Phase I studies, BNT162b2 was shown to have a better safety profile than the other three BioNTech candidates. [[180]](#cite_note-mulligan-189) [[42]](#cite_note-pmid33053279-42) [[181]](#cite_note-fosun11-190) [[182]](#cite_note-Herper,_STAT_2020.08.20-191) The Pivotal Phase II-III Trial with the lead vaccine candidate "BNT162b2" began in July. Preliminary results from [Phase I-II clinical trials](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research) on BNT162b2, published in October 2020, indicated potential for its safety and efficacy. [[42]](#cite_note-pmid33053279-42) During the same month, the [European Medicines Agency](/wiki/European_Medicines_Agency) (EMA) began a periodic review of BNT162b2. [[183]](#cite_note-192) The study of BNT162b2 is a continuous-phase [trial](/wiki/Clinical_trial) in [phase III](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_III) as of a " [randomized, placebo-controlled](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial), observer-blind, dose-finding, vaccine candidate-selection, and efficacy study in healthy individuals". [[43]](#cite_note-NCT04368728-43) The study expanded during mid-2020 to assess efficacy and safety of BNT162b2 in greater numbers of participants, reaching tens of thousands of people receiving test vaccinations in multiple countries in collaboration with Pfizer and Fosun. [[45]](#cite_note-herper-45) [[129]](#cite_note-fosun-138) The phase III trial assesses the safety, efficacy, tolerability, and [immunogenicity](/wiki/Immunogenicity) of BNT162b2 at a mid-dose level (two injections separated by 21 days) in three age groups: 12-15 years, 16-55 years or above 55 years. [[43]](#cite_note-NCT04368728-43) The Phase III results indicating a 95% efficacy of the developed vaccine were published on 18 November 2020. [[49]](#cite_note-BioNTechUpdate-49) For approval in the EU, an overall vaccine efficacy of 95% was confirmed by the EMA. [[184]](#cite_note-:0-193) The EMA clarified that the second dose should be administered three weeks after the first dose. [[185]](#cite_note-194) At 14 days after dose 1, the cumulative incidence begins to diverge between the vaccinated group and the placebo group. The highest concentration of neutralizing antibodies is reached 7 days after dose 2 in younger adults and 14 days after dose 2 in older adults. [[184]](#cite_note-:0-193) |Endpoint subgroup||Efficacy (95% |[[b]](#cite_note-196) The ongoing phase III trial, which is scheduled to run from 2020 to 2022, is designed to assess the ability of BNT162b2 to prevent severe infection, as well as the duration of [immune effect](/wiki/Immune_response). [[45]](#cite_note-herper-45) [[187]](#cite_note-edwards-197) [[158]](#cite_note-bbc-167) High [antibody activity](/wiki/Correlates_of_immunity/correlates_of_protection) persists for at least three months after the second dose, with an estimated antibody [half-life](/wiki/Half-life) of 55 days. From these data, one study suggested that antibodies might remain detectable for around 554 days. [[188]](#cite_note-198) Specific populations Pfizer and BioNTech started a Phase II-III randomized control trial in healthy pregnant women 18 years of age and older (NCT04754594). [[189]](#cite_note-pregnant_gov-199) The study will evaluate 30 mcg of BNT162b2 or placebo administered via intramuscular injection in two doses, 21 days apart. The Phase II portion of the study will include approximately 350 pregnant women randomized 1:1 to receive BNT162b2 or placebo at 27 to 34 weeks' gestation. The Phase III portion of this study will assess the safety, tolerability, and immunogenicity of BNT162b2 or placebo among pregnant women enrolled at 24 to 34 weeks' gestation. Pfizer and BioNTech announced on 18 February 2021 that the first participants received their first dose in this trial. [[190]](#cite_note-pregnant_pfizer-200) A study published in March 2021, in the [American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology](/wiki/American_Journal_of_Obstetrics_and_Gynecology) came to the conclusion that messenger RNA vaccines against the novel coronavirus, such as the Pfizer-BioNTech and [Moderna](/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine) vaccines were safe and effective at providing immunity against infection to pregnant and breastfeeding mothers. Furthermore, they found that naturally occurring [antibodies](/wiki/Antibody) created by the mother's immune system were passed on to their children via the [placenta](/wiki/Placenta) and/or breastmilk, thus resulting in [passive immunity](/wiki/Passive_immunity) among the child, effectively giving the child protection against the disease. The study also found that vaccine-induced immunity among the study's participants was stronger in a statistically significant way over immunity gained through recovery from a natural COVID19 infection. In addition, the study reported that the occurrence and intensity of potential side effects in those undergoing pregnancy or lactating was very similar to those expected from non-pregnant populations, remaining generally very minor and well tolerated, mostly including injection site soreness, minor headaches, muscles aches or fatigue for a short period of time. [[191]](#cite_note-201) In January 2021, Pfizer said it had finished enrolling 2,259 children aged between 12 and 15 years to study the vaccine's safety and efficacy. [[192]](#cite_note-202) On 31 March 2021, Pfizer and BioNTech announced from initial Phase III trial data that the vaccine is 100% effective for those aged 12 to 15 years of age, with trials for those younger still in progress. [[193]](#cite_note-203) A research letter published in [JAMA](/wiki/JAMA) reported that the vaccines appeared to be safe for immunosuppressed organ transplant recipients, but that the resulting antibody response was considerably poorer than in the non-immunocompromised population after only one dose. The paper admitted the limitation of only reviewing the data following the first dose of a two-dose cycle vaccine. [[194]](#cite_note-204) On 2 November 2021, [The BMJ](/wiki/The_BMJ) published a piece by journalist [Paul D. Thacker](/wiki/Paul_D._Thacker) alleging there has been "poor practice" at [Ventavia](/w/index.php?title=Ventavia&action=edit&redlink=1), one of the companies involved in the [phase III](/wiki/Phases_of_clinical_research#Phase_III) evaluation trials of the Pfizer vaccine. [[195]](#cite_note-BMJ-20211102-205) The report was enthusiastically embraced by [anti-vaccination](/wiki/Anti-vaccination) activists. [David Gorski](/wiki/David_Gorski) commented in [Science-Based Medicine](/wiki/Science-Based_Medicine) that Thacker's article presented facts without necessary context to misleading effect, playing up the seriousness of the noted problems. [[196]](#cite_note-206) Authorizations Although jointly developed with Pfizer, [[197]](#cite_note-ComirnatyBoosterTrialPress-207) Comirnaty is based on BioNTech's proprietary mRNA technology, [[197]](#cite_note-ComirnatyBoosterTrialPress-207) and BioNTech holds the [Marketing Authorization](/wiki/Marketing_authorisation) in the United States, the European Union, the UK, and Canada; [[197]](#cite_note-ComirnatyBoosterTrialPress-207) expedited licenses such as the US [emergency use authorization](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorization) (EUA) are held jointly with Pfizer in many countries. [[197]](#cite_note-ComirnatyBoosterTrialPress-207) Expedited The United Kingdom's [Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency](/wiki/Medicines_and_Healthcare_products_Regulatory_Agency) (MHRA) gave the vaccine "rapid temporary regulatory approval to address significant public health issues such as a pandemic" on 2 December 2020, which it is permitted to do under the [Medicines Act 1968](/wiki/Medicines_Act_1968). [[56]](#cite_note-ukgov12-22-57) It is the first COVID19 vaccine to be approved for national use after undergoing large scale trials, [[198]](#cite_note-208) and the first [mRNA vaccine](/wiki/MRNA_vaccine) to be authorized for use in humans. [[56]](#cite_note-ukgov12-22-57) [[199]](#cite_note-mueller-209) The United Kingdom thus became the first [Western country](/wiki/Western_world) to approve a COVID19 vaccine for national use, [[200]](#cite_note-bbcuk-210) although the decision to fast-track the vaccine was criticized by some experts. [[201]](#cite_note-211) After the United Kingdom, the following countries and regions expedited processes to approve the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID19 vaccine for use: Argentina, United Arab Emirates, [[229]](#cite_note-emirateswoman.com-239) the United States, [[230]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20201211-240) and Vietnam. [[231]](#cite_note-241) The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) authorized it for emergency use. [[232]](#cite_note-242) [[233]](#cite_note-243) [[234]](#cite_note-244) [[235]](#cite_note-245) In the United States, an [emergency use authorization](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorization) (EUA) is "a mechanism to facilitate the availability and use of medical countermeasures, including vaccines, during public health emergencies, such as the current COVID19 pandemic", according to the [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA). [[236]](#cite_note-fda-eua-246) Pfizer applied for an EUA on 20 November 2020, [[237]](#cite_note-247) and the FDA approved the application three weeks later on 11 December 2020. The US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices) (ACIP) approved recommendations for vaccination of those aged sixteen years or older. [[238]](#cite_note-248) [[239]](#cite_note-249) Following the EUA issuance, BioNTech and Pfizer continued the Phase III clinical trial to finalize safety and efficacy data, leading to application for licensure (approval) of the vaccine in the United States. [[245]](#cite_note-255) [[246]](#cite_note-256) On 5 May 2021, [Health Canada](/wiki/Health_Canada) authorized the vaccine for people aged 12 to 15. [[293]](#cite_note-303) [[294]](#cite_note-304) In October 2022, the FDA amended the authorization for the bivalent booster to cover people aged five years of age and older. [[295]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20221012-305) In December 2022, the FDA amended the authorization for the bivalent booster to be used as the third dose in people aged six months through four years of age. [[296]](#cite_note-306) Society and culture About 649 million doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine, including about 55 million doses in children and adolescents (below 18 years of age) were administered in the EU/EEA from authorization to 26 June 2022. [[297]](#cite_note-307) Brand names BNT162b2 was the code name during development and testing, [[42]](#cite_note-pmid33053279-42) [[52]](#cite_note-pmid33301246-52) tozinameran is the recommended [international nonproprietary is the [[2]](#cite_note-Comirnaty_EPAR-2) According to BioNTech, the name Comirnaty "represents a the terms COVID19, mRNA, community, and immunity". [[299]](#cite_note-fiercepharma-309) [[300]](#cite_note-310) Economics Pfizer reported revenue of US$154 million from the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine in 2020, [[175]](#cite_note-Pfizer_Annual_Report_2020-184) and $36 billion in 2021. [[301]](#cite_note-Pfizer_Annual_Report_2021-311) [[302]](#cite_note-312) In July 2020, the vaccine development program [Operation Warp Speed](/wiki/Operation_Warp_Speed) placed an advance order of US$1.95 billion with Pfizer to manufacture 100 million doses of a COVID19 vaccine for use in the United States if the vaccine was shown to be safe and effective. [[41]](#cite_note-nytimes-2020-11-09-41) [[303]](#cite_note-pbio-313) [[304]](#cite_note-314) [[305]](#cite_note-yahoo-315) [[306]](#cite_note-316) By mid-December 2020, Pfizer had agreements to supply 300 million doses to the European Union, [[307]](#cite_note-317) 120 million doses to Japan, [[308]](#cite_note-318) 40 million doses (10 million before 2021) to the United Kingdom, [[158]](#cite_note-bbc-167) 20 million doses to Canada, [[309]](#cite_note-cbc-319) an unspecified number of doses to Singapore, [[310]](#cite_note-320) and 34.4 million doses to Mexico. [[311]](#cite_note-321) Fosun also has agreements to supply 10 million doses to Hong Kong and [Macau](/wiki/Macau). [[312]](#cite_note-322) Accounts of how Pfizer's got its way into a large deal to provide 1.8 billion doses of its vaccine to the European Union were described by the New York Times as "a striking alignment of political survival and corporate hustle". [[313]](#cite_note-323) Access Pfizer has been accused of hindering [vaccine equity](/wiki/Vaccine_equity). In 2021, Pfizer delivered only 39% of the contractually agreed doses to the [COVAX](/wiki/COVAX) programme, a number that equals 1.5% of all vaccines produced by Pfizer. The company sold 67% of their doses to [high-income countries](/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy) and sold none directly to [low-income countries](/wiki/Developing_country). [[314]](#cite_note-324) Pfizer actively lobbied against the [temporary lift of intellectual property rights](/wiki/Waiver_from_certain_provisions_of_the_TRIPS_Agreement_for_the_Prevention,_Containment_and_Treatment_of_COVID-19) which would allow the vaccine to be produced by others without having to pay a royalty fee. [[315]](#cite_note-325) [[316]](#cite_note-326) Misinformation Videos on [video-sharing platforms](/wiki/Social_media) circulated around May 2021 showing people having [magnets](/wiki/Magnets) stick to their arms after receiving the vaccine, purportedly demonstrating the [conspiracy theory that vaccines contain microchips](/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation#Vaccines), but these videos have been debunked. [^](#cite_ref-80)This is a type of study where researchers recruit two groups: people who test positive for the disease (cases) and those who test negative (controls) (Vandenbroucke 2019). They then survey these individuals for factors which may have affected whether or not they developed the disease (in this case, vaccination status) (Patel 2020). In the case of Lopez Bernal et al, they also assessed which [variant](/wiki/Variants_of_SARS-CoV-2)each "case" contracted (e.g. alpha [B.1.1.7] or delta [B.1.617.2]) using both [RT-PCR](/wiki/RT-PCR)testing and [whole genome sequencing](/wiki/Whole_genome_sequencing). To evaluate efficacy, the researchers determined how much less likely a person was to contract each variant based on their vaccination status. In this case, a person who received two doses of the Pfizer vaccine was 93.7% less likely to contract the alpha variant and 88.0% less likely to contract the delta variant, when compared to an unvaccinated person. - Vandenbroucke JP, Pearce N (November 2019).
